matrix.description: Nitrogen-containing organic compounds with pharmacological activity. Examples: berberine, caffeine, morphine, nicotine.
matrix.notes: Extraction depends on salt form vs free base. Acidic solvents (vinegar) convert alkaloids to salts, improving aqueous solubility. Some alkaloids (e.g., berberine) are water-soluble as salts.

matrix.description: Aromatic terpene-based compounds responsible for plant fragrance and many therapeutic effects. Examples: menthol, thymol, linalool, chamazulene.
matrix.notes: Volatile oils are lipophilic and require high-alcohol or oil-based solvents. Hot water causes evaporative loss — cover infusions to retain volatile oils. Steam distillation is the standard isolation method but not relevant to simple extraction.

matrix.description: Complex carbohydrates including immunomodulating beta-glucans and structural fibers. Examples: inulin, beta-glucan, arabinogalactans.
matrix.notes: Water is the primary solvent for polysaccharides. Hot water decoction is optimal. Ethanol actually precipitates polysaccharides out of solution — this is used industrially to isolate them. Dual extraction (water + alcohol sequentially) captures both polysaccharides and alcohol-soluble constituents.

matrix.description: Polyphenolic compounds that bind and precipitate proteins. Hydrolyzable tannins are esters of gallic or ellagic acid with glucose. Examples: gallotannins, ellagitannins.
matrix.notes: Hydrolyzable tannins are more water-soluble than condensed tannins. Glycerin is notably effective for tannin extraction. Medium-alcohol tinctures (40-60%) capture tannins well. High alcohol concentrations can reduce tannin solubility.
